messageBody:
Jeff Grigg wrote:

> For example, "set" methods typically return void. You can test "setX"
> by calling it, and verify that the result of "getX" changed. [This is
> just an example. Testing get and set methods is typically a waste of
> time. I'll assume that your void-return-method does something *non-
> trivial* and useful.]

A popular myth. I've lost count of how many bugs I've found in set and
get methods, as well as other methods that were "too simple to fail."

Remember, even if such a method is simple today it may not be tomorrow.
One big reason we use set and get methods instead of direct field access
is precisely because the implementation may change. What merely sets a
variable today may write into a database tomorrow, or verify an
additional constraint. Writing test code for setters and getters insures
that the code still works as originally anticipated as it becomes more
complex in the future. It's easier to write the test code when the
implementation is simple and predictable than when it is more complex.
